<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	31
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage33"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table details the U.S., Canadian, and international rig activity and West Texas Intermediate Oil
	prices for the past nine quarters ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 on a quarterly basis:
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT" ALIGN="CENTER">
<IMG SRC="http://content.edgar-online.com/edgar_conv_img/2017/02/17/0001193125-17-047937_G313669G75R38.JPG" ALT="LOGO">
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Source: Rig count: Baker Hughes, Inc. (
<U>
	www.bakerhughes.com
</U>
	); West Texas Intermediate Crude Price: Department of
	Energy, Energy Information Administration (
<U>
	www.eia.doe.gov
</U>
	).
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The average price per barrel of West Texas Intermediate Crude was $43.15 in 2016, a
	decrease of 11% over the average price for 2015 of $48.71 per barrel.&nbsp;The average natural gas price was $2.49 per mmbtu, a decrease of 5% compared to the 2015 average of $2.61 per mmbtu.&nbsp;Average rig activity worldwide decreased 32% for the
	full year in 2016 compared to 2015.&nbsp;The average crude oil price for the fourth quarter of 2016 was $49.14 per barrel, and natural gas was $3.01 per mmbtu.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At February 10, 2017, there were 1,093 rigs actively drilling in North America, compared to the fourth quarter average of 765 rigs, an increase of 43%. The
	price for West Texas Intermediate Crude Oil was $53.86 per barrel at February 10, 2017, an increase of 10% from the fourth quarter of 2016 average. The price for natural gas was $3.03 per mmbtu at February 10, 2017, an increase of 1% from the fourth
	quarter of 2016 average.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	32
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage34"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	National Oilwell Varco, Inc. generated revenue of $7.3&nbsp;billion in 2016, a decrease of 51% from the prior year due to declining oil and gas prices
	resulting in reduced drilling activity and demand for oilfield equipment and services. Average 2016 worldwide rig count (as measured by Baker Hughes) decreased 32% in comparison to 2015. The broad-based decline in activity led all four of the
	Company&#146;s reporting segments to post lower year-over-year revenues.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the year ended December 31, 2016, the Company reported an operating loss of
	$2,411&nbsp;million compared to an operating loss of $390&nbsp;million in 2015, and a net loss from continuing operations of $2,412&nbsp;million, or $6.41 per share compared to a net loss of $769&nbsp;million or $1.99 per share during 2015.
	Operating loss excluding other items (as defined in the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	&#147;Non-GAAP
</FONT>
	Financial Measures and Reconciliations&#148; in Results of Operations) was $381&nbsp;million in 2016 and earnings (loss) per share
	excluding other items was $(0.84) in 2016, a 130% decrease from $2.80 per share in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	For the fourth quarter ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, revenue was
	$1.7&nbsp;billion, a $46&nbsp;million or 3% increase compared to the third quarter of 2016. The Company reported a net loss of $714&nbsp;million from continuing operations, or $1.90 per fully diluted share, an increase of $648&nbsp;million, or $1.72
	per fully diluted share. Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, revenue decreased $1,030&nbsp;million or 38%, and net income from continuing operations increased $809&nbsp;million.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	During the fourth quarter of 2016, third quarter of 2016, and fourth quarter of 2015,
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	pre-tax
</FONT>
	other items (severance,
	facility closures, asset impairments, foreign exchange losses, write-downs, and other) were $694&nbsp;million, $1,078&nbsp;million and $1,773&nbsp;million, respectively. Excluding the other items from all periods, fourth quarter 2016 earnings
	(losses) per share excluding other items were $(0.15) per fully diluted share, compared to $(0.34) per fully diluted share in the third quarter of 2016 and earnings of $0.23 per fully diluted share in the fourth quarter of 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating profit (loss) excluding other items was $(72) million or (4.3)% of sales in the fourth quarter of 2016, compared to $(108) million or (6.6)% of
	sales in the third quarter of 2016, and $141&nbsp;million or 5.2% of sales in the fourth quarter of 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Segment Performance
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rig Systems
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Rig Systems segment
	generated $2.4&nbsp;billion in revenue and $969&nbsp;million in operating loss, or (40.6)% of revenue, during 2016. Compared to the prior year, revenue decreased 66% and operating profit dollars decreased 173%. For the fourth quarter of 2016, the
	segment generated $426&nbsp;million in revenue and $81&nbsp;million in operating loss, or (19.0)% of revenue. Compared to the prior quarter, revenue decreased $44&nbsp;million or 9%, and operating loss decreased $881&nbsp;million or 92%. Compared to
	the fourth quarter of 2015, revenue decreased $589&nbsp;million or 58%, and operating profit decreased $227&nbsp;million or 155%. Fourth quarter 2016 revenue out of backlog for the Rig Systems segment decreased 11% sequentially and 62%
	year-over-year on fewer shipments of land rigs and postponed delivery dates of some offshore projects. During the fourth quarter of 2016, the segment received $115&nbsp;million in new orders, primarily composed of discreet capital equipment
	components including top drives, blowout preventers and offshore cranes.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Year-end
</FONT>
	backlog for the segment was $2.5&nbsp;billion, a 10% decline sequentially and a 59% decrease year-over-year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rig Aftermarket
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Rig Aftermarket
	segment generated $1.4&nbsp;billion in revenue and $229&nbsp;million in operating profit, or 16.2% of revenue, during 2016. Compared to the prior year, revenue decreased 44% and operating profit dollars decreased 65%. For the fourth quarter of 2016,
	the segment generated $339&nbsp;million in revenue and $26&nbsp;million in operating profit, or 7.7% of revenue. Compared to the prior quarter, revenue increased $17&nbsp;million or 5%, and operating profit decreased $46&nbsp;million or 64%.
	Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, revenue decreased $230&nbsp;million or 40%, and operating profit decreased $112&nbsp;million or 81%. Revenue decreased year-over-year as drilling contractors reduced spending and depleted existing spares
	inventories rather than purchase new, and deferred repair and maintenance work on their rig fleets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Wellbore Technologies
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Wellbore Technologies segment generated $2.2&nbsp;billion in revenue and $770&nbsp;million in operating loss, or (35.0)% of revenue, for the
	full year 2016. Compared to the prior year, revenue decreased 41% and operating loss decreased 51%. For the fourth quarter of 2016, the segment generated $531&nbsp;million in revenue and $439&nbsp;million in operating loss, or (82.7)% of revenue.
	Compared to the prior quarter, revenue increased $5&nbsp;million or 1%, and operating loss increased $345&nbsp;million. Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015, revenue decreased $226&nbsp;million, and operating loss decreased $1,275&nbsp;million.
	Revenue decreased due to lower levels of worldwide drilling activity, resulting in less demand for the segment&#146;s services and product offerings. Year-over-year operating margins were impacted by lower volumes, but were more than offset by the
	$1,634&nbsp;million impairment charge related to goodwill and a certain indefinite-lived trade name recorded in 2015 that did not repeat in 2016 and cost reduction efforts.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	33
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage35"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions segment generated $2.2&nbsp;billion in revenue and $266&nbsp;million in operating loss, or
	(11.9)% of revenue, for the full year 2016. Compared to the prior year, revenue decreased 33% and operating profit decreased $453&nbsp;million. Year-over-year revenue decreases were attributable to reduced demand and customers delaying receipt of
	finished orders for onshore completion and production equipment in response to commodity price declines. For the fourth quarter of 2016, the segment generated $602&nbsp;million in revenue and $134&nbsp;million in operating loss, or (22.3)% of
	revenue. Compared to the prior quarter, revenue increased $59&nbsp;million or 11%, and operating loss increased $73&nbsp;million. Sequentially, operating loss increased on pricing pressures and product mix. Compared to the fourth quarter of 2015,
	revenue decreased $144&nbsp;million and operating profit decreased $138&nbsp;million as lower levels of worldwide drilling activity resulted in reduced sales across most product lines. Fourth quarter 2016 revenue out of backlog for the
	Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions segment increased 12% sequentially and decreased 22% year-over-year. During the fourth quarter of 2016, the segment received $370&nbsp;million in new orders.
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Year-end
</FONT>
	backlog for the segment was $818&nbsp;million, an increase of 1% sequentially and a 15% decline year-over-year.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Oil&nbsp;&amp; Gas Equipment and
	Services Market
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Over the past decade, technological advancements in the oilfield equipment and service space unlocked production from formations that
	were previously deemed uneconomic, especially in North America. From 2004 to 2014 global oil and liquids supply increased dramatically from U.S. unconventional resources, deep-water (defined as water depths greater than 400 feet) resources and from
	other sources. The advances in technology combined with relatively high commodity prices caused by growing demand enabled and sustained an increase in global drilling activity. Global supply started to catch up to demand, and in the latter half of
	2014, demand growth in areas such as Asia, Europe and the U.S. weakened while drilling activity remained strong and production continued to grow. As a result, global inventories of crude and refined products grew and the price of oil declined
	significantly during early 2015, remaining depressed throughout the year and undergoing another major reduction toward the end of 2015. In early 2016, the market witnessed oil trading in the high $20 per barrel range, prices not seen since 2003.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In response to rapidly deteriorating market conditions, operators acutely reduced both operating and capital expenditures. Orders for our equipment and
	services slowed and rig counts declined rapidly with active U.S. drilling rig counts hitting 70&nbsp;year lows and international rig counts reaching decade lows during the second quarter of 2016. As a result of the sharp cutback in activity,
	production began to decline in certain areas of the world and commodity prices started to rebound as oil markets commenced the process of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	re-balancing.
</FONT>
	The market downturn began to stabilize during the second
	half of 2016 and, aided by OPEC and certain other countries announcing production cuts of 1.7&nbsp;million barrels per day, showed early signs of improvement during the fourth quarter. The price of West Texas Intermediate Cushing Crude ended the
	year at $53.72 a barrel.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Outlook
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Activity in North
	America increased sharply off historical lows during the last two quarters of 2016 and declines in supply, assisted by the OPEC production cuts, appear to be rebalancing the market; however, global stocks of crude oil and refined product remain
	bloated and challenging conditions persist. Consequently, we are cautious in our outlook for 2017, and anticipate that our customers will continue to moderate capital expenditures until a there is more certainty in a sustainable recovery in
	commodity prices.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	While North America has exhibited the signs of a burgeoning recovery, activity levels remain well below prior cyclical highs.
	International activity, which has been slower to fall than North American activity, appears to be approaching a bottom, which could be achieved in the first half of 2017. Offshore activity, which has longer project cycle times and, in certain
	instances, more challenged economics, may continue to decline throughout 2017.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Low activity levels result in an oversupply of service capacity and
	capital equipment, creating challenging prospects for many of our customers in the form of reduced volumes and pricing pressures. In this environment, contractors have been hesitant to invest in their existing equipment to conserve as much capital
	as possible. Equipment has been neglected and idle fleets have been stripped of parts to sustain assets that remains active. Additionally, certain equipment becomes less desirable and obsolete as equipment manufacturers develop new technologies and
	produce more efficient equipment that improves efficiencies and lowers the marginal cost of supply for oil and gas operating companies. As a result, the industry may retire a significant portion of the installed base of capital equipment that
	existed at the beginning of this cyclical downturn, causing a sharp rebound in newbuild orders if commodity prices continue to recover and activity levels increase.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Our global customer base includes national oil companies, international oil companies, independent oil and gas companies, onshore and offshore service
	companies and others whose strategies and reactions to low commodity prices vary. Likewise, we expect the slope and timing of revenue decline, stabilization and recovery will be different across our operating regions and our four business segments.
	Elements of our Wellbore Technologies and Rig Aftermarket segments are expected to see a faster recovery as drilling of new wells increases, while a strong recovery for the more capital equipment oriented businesses within our Completion&nbsp;&amp;
	Production Solutions and Rig Systems segments may come later in the cycle.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	34
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage36"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Throughout 2017 we will continue to focus on what we can control, in the form of sizing our operations with
	anticipated levels of activity while continuing to invest in developing and acquiring new products, technologies and operations that advance our longer term strategic goals. The Company has a history of implementing cost-control measures and
	downsizing in response to depressed market conditions as well as cost effectively ramping operations to capitalize on rapidly increasing demand. The Company remains optimistic regarding longer-term market fundamentals as existing oil and gas fields
	continue to deplete and numerous major projects to replenish supply have been deferred or canceled while global demand continues to grow.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	35
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage37"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<A NAME="FIS_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Results of Operations
</B>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_13"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and December&nbsp;31, 2015
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following table summarizes the Company&#146;s revenue and operating profit (loss) by operating segment in 2016 and 2015 (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="92%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" ALIGN="CENTER">

</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" WIDTH="4%">
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>
<TD>
</TD>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rig Systems
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from
	Rig Systems for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $2,386&nbsp;million, a decrease of $4,578&nbsp;million (65.7%)&nbsp;compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The decrease was due to lower land rig shipments and delayed delivery
	dates of certain offshore projects.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating loss from Rig Systems was $969&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, a decrease of
	$2,291&nbsp;million (173.3%)&nbsp;compared to 2015. Operating profit (loss) percentage decreased to (40.6)%, from 19.0% in 2015. Operating profit percentage decreased primarily due to lower volumes and a $972&nbsp;million impairment charge incurred
	on the carrying value of goodwill during the third quarter of 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit are other items related to costs associated with a
	Voluntary Early Retirement Plan established by the Company during the first quarters of 2016 and 2015, costs related to severance and facility closures, and asset write-downs. Other items included in operating profit for Rig Systems were
	$218&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $105&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Rig Systems segment
	monitors its capital equipment backlog to plan its business. New orders are added to backlog only when the Company receives a firm written order for major drilling rig components or a signed contract related to a construction project. In light of
	the vote by the shareholders of SETE Brasil Participacoes SA to authorize Sete to file for bankruptcy, and a further decline in drilling activity during the first half of the year to record lows and the resulting effect on certain other customers,
	the Company removed $2.1&nbsp;billion of orders from its backlog in the first quarter of 2016. Some of the contracts for these orders remain in place and are enforceable. If these customers obtain funding to continue their projects, the Company may
	pursue resumption of construction and update the backlog accordingly. The capital equipment backlog was $2.5&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2016, a decrease of $3.6&nbsp;billion, or 59%,&nbsp;from backlog of $6.1&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31,
	2015.&nbsp;Numerous factors may affect the timing of revenue out of backlog. Considering these factors, the Company reasonably expects approximately $1.0&nbsp;billion of revenue out of backlog in 2017 and approximately $1.5&nbsp;billion of revenue
	out of backlog in 2018 and thereafter. At December&nbsp;31, 2016, approximately 81% of the capital equipment backlog was for offshore products and approximately 82% of the capital equipment backlog was destined for international markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	36
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage38"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rig Aftermarket
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from Rig Aftermarket for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $1,416&nbsp;million, a decrease of $1,099&nbsp;million (43.7%) compared to the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The decrease was due to lower global drilling activity which has caused customers to use existing inventories and components from idle and unused rigs to repair better utilized rigs rather than purchase new.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating profit from Rig Aftermarket was $229&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, a decrease of $423&nbsp;million (64.9%) compared to
	2015. Operating profit percentage decreased to 16.2%, from 25.9% in 2015. Operating profit percentage decreased primarily due to lower volumes and pricing pressure.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit are other items related to costs associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan established by the Company during the first
	quarters of 2016 and 2015, costs related to severance and facility closures, and asset write-downs. Other items included in operating profit for Rig Aftermarket were $65&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $12&nbsp;million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Wellbore Technologies
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from Wellbore Technologies for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $2,199&nbsp;million, a decrease of $1,519&nbsp;million (40.9%) compared to the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.&nbsp;The decrease was due to lower drilling activity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating loss from Wellbore Technologies was $770&nbsp;million
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, a decrease of $803&nbsp;million (51.0%) compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.&nbsp;Operating loss percentage decreased to 35.0% from 42.3% in 2015. Operating loss decreased due to
	$1,658&nbsp;million in goodwill and intangible asset impairment charges, which occurred in the fourth quarter of 2015 and did not repeat in 2016, partially offset by a decrease in drilling activity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit are other items related to costs associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan established by the Company during the first
	quarters of 2016 and 2015, costs related to severance and facility closures, and asset write-downs. Other items included in operating profit for Wellbore Technologies were $476&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 and
	$117&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $2,241&nbsp;million, a decrease of $1,124&nbsp;million
	(33.4%)&nbsp;compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.&nbsp;The decrease was due to lower market activity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating profit (loss) from
	Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions was $(266) million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to $187&nbsp;million for 2015, a decrease of $453&nbsp;million (242.2%).&nbsp;Operating profit (loss) percentage decreased to (11.9)%
	from 5.6% in 2015. This decrease was due to the overall decline in market activity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit are other items related to costs
	associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan established by the Company during the first quarters of 2016 and 2015; costs related to severance and facility closures; items related to acquisitions, such as transaction costs, the amortization of
	backlog and inventory that was stepped up to fair value during purchase accounting; and asset write-downs. Other items included in operating profit for Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions were $274&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016 and $101&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Completion&nbsp;&amp; Productions Solutions segment monitors
	its capital equipment backlog to plan its business. New orders are added to backlog only when the Company receives a firm written order for major completion and production components or a signed contract related to a construction project. The
	capital equipment backlog was $818&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2016, a decrease of $151&nbsp;million, or 16%&nbsp;from backlog of $969&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.&nbsp;Numerous factors may affect the timing of revenue out of
	backlog. Considering these factors, the Company reasonably expects approximately $770&nbsp;million of revenue out of backlog in 2017 and approximately $48&nbsp;million of revenue out of backlog in 2018 and thereafter. At December&nbsp;31, 2016,
	approximately 71% of the capital equipment backlog was for offshore products and approximately 87% of the capital equipment backlog was destined for international markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Eliminations
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Eliminations in operating profit were
	$635&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to $978&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. This change is primarily due to lower intersegment sales. Sales from one segment to another generally are priced at
	estimated equivalent commercial selling prices; however, segments originating an external sale are credited with the full profit to the company. Eliminations include intercompany transactions conducted between the four reporting segments that are
	eliminated in consolidation. Intercompany transactions within each reporting segment are eliminated within each reporting segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	37
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage39"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other income (expense), net
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other income (expense), net were expenses of $101&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 compared to expenses of $123&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. The decrease was primarily due to lower foreign exchange losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Provision for income taxes
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The effective tax rate for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016 was 7.9%, compared to (30.2)% for 2015. Impairment of goodwill not deductible for tax
	purposes, lower tax rates on losses incurred in foreign jurisdictions, and an increase in valuation allowance on deferred taxes, which, when applied to losses generated during the period, resulted in a lower effective tax rate than the U.S.
	statutory rate. Included in the increase in valuation allowance is $404&nbsp;million recorded against excess foreign tax credits that are not expected to be realized before expiration in the current depressed market conditions.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	38
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rig Systems
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from
	Rig Systems for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $6,964&nbsp;million, a decrease of $2,884&nbsp;million (29.3%)&nbsp;compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease was due to lower land rig shipments and delayed delivery
	dates of certain offshore projects.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating profit from Rig Systems was $1,322&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of
	$796&nbsp;million (37.6%)&nbsp;compared to 2014. Operating profit percentage decreased to 19.0%, from 21.5% in 2014. Operating profit percentage decreased primarily due to lower volumes. Despite the strong fall off in revenue, strategic cost
	management efforts significantly reduced the decline in operating profit percentage.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit are other items related to costs
	associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan established by the Company during the first quarter of 2015 and costs related to severance and facility closures. Other items included in operating profit for Rig Systems were $105&nbsp;million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and nil for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Rig Systems segment monitors its capital equipment backlog
	to plan its business. New orders are added to backlog only when the Company receives a firm written order for major drilling rig components or a signed contract related to a construction project. The capital equipment backlog was $6.1&nbsp;billion
	at December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of $6.4&nbsp;billion, or 52%,&nbsp;from backlog of $12.5&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2014.&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2015, approximately 90% of the capital equipment backlog was for offshore products and
	approximately 93% of the capital equipment backlog was destined for international markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Rig Aftermarket
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from Rig Aftermarket for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $2,515&nbsp;million, a decrease of $707&nbsp;million (21.9%) compared to the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease was due to lower global drilling activity which has caused customers to use existing inventories and components from idle and unused rigs to repair better utilized rigs rather than purchase new.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating profit from Rig Aftermarket was $652&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of $283&nbsp;million (30.3%) compared to
	2014. Operating profit percentage decreased to 25.9%, from 29.0% in 2014. Operating profit percentage decreased primarily due to lower volumes and pricing pressure.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	39
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage41"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit are other items related to costs associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan
	established by the Company during the first quarter of 2015 and costs related to severance and facility closures. Other items included in operating profit for Rig Aftermarket were $12&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and nil
	for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Wellbore Technologies
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from Wellbore Technologies for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $3,718&nbsp;million, a decrease of $2,004&nbsp;million (35.0%) compared to the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.&nbsp;The decrease was due to lower drilling activity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating loss from Wellbore Technologies was
	$1,573&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to operating profit of $1,000&nbsp;million for 2014, a decrease of $2,573&nbsp;million (257.3%).&nbsp;Operating profit percentage decreased to negative 42.3% from 17.5% in 2014.
	Operating profit decreased mainly due to a $1,658&nbsp;million impairment charge incurred on the carrying value of goodwill in the segment&#146;s Drilling&nbsp;&amp; Intervention and Drill Pipe business units as well as a certain indefinite-lived
	trade name associated with this segment in the fourth quarter of 2015, as well as the overall decrease in drilling activity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit
	are other items related to costs associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan established by the Company during the first quarter of 2015 and costs related to severance and facility closures. Other items included in operating profit for
	Wellbore Technologies were $117&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and $6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Revenue from
	Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 was $3,365&nbsp;million, a decrease of $1,280&nbsp;million (27.6%)&nbsp;compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.&nbsp;The decrease was due lower market
	activity.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Operating profit from Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions was $187&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to
	$730&nbsp;million for 2014, a decrease of $543&nbsp;million (74.4%).&nbsp;Operating profit percentage decreased to 5.6% from 15.7% in 2014. This decrease was due to the overall decrease in market activity as well as $24&nbsp;million in impairment
	charges incurred on intangible assets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Included in operating profit are other items related to costs associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan
	established by the Company during the first quarter of 2015; costs related to severance and facility closures; items related to acquisitions, such as transaction costs, the amortization of backlog and inventory that was stepped up to fair value
	during purchase accounting. Other items included in operating profit for Completion&nbsp;&amp; Production Solutions were $101&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and $10&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Completion&nbsp;&amp; Productions Solutions segment monitors its capital equipment backlog to plan its business. New orders are added to backlog only when
	the Company receives a firm written order for major completion and production components or a signed contract related to a construction project. The capital equipment backlog was $969&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of
	$810&nbsp;million, or 46%&nbsp;from backlog of $1,780&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2015, approximately 75% of the capital equipment backlog was for offshore products and approximately 87% of the capital equipment
	backlog was destined for international markets.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Eliminations
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Eliminations in operating profit were $978&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $1,170&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. This change is primarily due to lower intersegment sales. Sales from one segment to another generally are priced at estimated equivalent commercial selling prices; however, segments originating an external sale are credited
	with the full profit to the company. Eliminations include intercompany transactions conducted between the four reporting segments that are eliminated in consolidation. Intercompany transactions within each reporting segment are eliminated within
	each reporting segment.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Other income (expense), net
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Other income (expense), net were expenses of $123&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to expenses of $90&nbsp;million for the year
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase was primarily due to higher foreign exchange losses.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	Provision for income taxes
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The effective tax rate for the year ended December 31, 2015 was (30.2)%, compared to 29.7% for 2014. Compared to the U.S. statutory rate, the effective tax
	rate was positively impacted in the period by a domestic loss, the effect of lower tax rates on income earned in foreign jurisdictions, a reduction of deferred taxes due to decreases in statutory tax rates of foreign jurisdictions, and foreign
	exchange losses for tax reporting in Norway. The effective tax rate was negatively impacted by additional U.S. tax on foreign dividends net of foreign tax credits, the recognition and settlement of an uncertain tax position in a foreign
	jurisdiction, and nondeductible expenses. The nondeductible expenses primarily consist of non-deductible goodwill impaired during the year ended December 31, 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	40
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	Non-GAAP
</FONT>
	Financial Measures and Reconciliations
</I>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	In an effort to provide investors with additional information regarding our results as determined by GAAP, we disclose various
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures in our quarterly earnings press releases and other public disclosures. The primary
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures we focus on herein are:
	(i)&nbsp;operating profit (loss) excluding other items, (ii)&nbsp;operating profit (loss) percentage excluding other items, and (iii)&nbsp;diluted earnings (loss) per share excluding other items. Each of these financial measures excludes the impact
	of certain amounts as further identified below and has not been calculated in accordance with GAAP. A reconciliation of each of these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures to its most comparable GAAP financial measure
	is included below.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We use these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures internally to evaluate and manage the Company&#146;s
	operations because we believe it provides useful supplemental information regarding the Company&#146;s
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-going
</FONT>
	economic performance. We have chosen to provide this information to investors to enable them to
	perform more meaningful comparisons of operating results, and as a means to emphasize the results of
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	on-going
</FONT>
	operations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The following tables set forth the reconciliations of these
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-GAAP
</FONT>
	financial measures to their most comparable GAAP
	financial measures (in millions, except per share data):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;

<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT">
<TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P STYLE=" MARGIN-TOP:0PT ; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; MARGIN-LEFT:5.00EM; TEXT-INDENT:-1.00EM; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">

</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(1)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Included in operating profit (loss) are other items related to goodwill and intangible asset impairments.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN; FONT-SIZE:10PT" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="TOP" ALIGN="LEFT">
	(2)
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="LEFT" VALIGN="TOP">
	Included in operating profit (loss) are other items related to costs associated with a Voluntary Early Retirement Plan established by the Company during the first quarters of 2016 and 2015; costs related to severance
	and facility closures; items related to acquisitions, such as transaction costs and the amortization of backlog; the costs of the
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	spin-off
</FONT>
	of the Company&#146;s distribution business and certain legal costs.
	Other items that are included in other income (expense), net were $12&nbsp;million and $54&nbsp;million for the three months and year ended December&nbsp;31, 2016, respectively; nil for each of the three months and for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, respectively; and $10&nbsp;million for the three months ended September, 2016.
</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company assesses liquidity in terms of its ability to generate cash to fund operating, investing and financing activities. The Company remains in a strong
	financial position, with resources available to reinvest in existing businesses, strategic acquisitions and capital expenditures to meet short- and long-term objectives. The Company believes that cash on hand, cash generated from expected results of
	operations and amounts available under its revolving credit facility will be sufficient to fund operations, anticipated working capital needs and other cash requirements including capital expenditures, debt and interest payments and dividend
	payments for the foreseeable future.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, the Company had cash and cash equivalents of $1,408&nbsp;million, and total debt of
	$3,214&nbsp;million.&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2015, cash and cash equivalents were $2,080&nbsp;million and total debt was $3,909&nbsp;million.&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2016, approximately $1,157&nbsp;million of the $1,408&nbsp;million of cash
	and cash equivalents was held by our foreign subsidiaries, of which $1,126&nbsp;million would be subject to a 35% U.S. income tax rate, offset by any available foreign tax credits if repatriated. However, our current plans are to permanently
	reinvest these funds outside of the U.S. If opportunities to invest in the U.S. are greater than available cash balances that are not subject to income tax, rather than repatriating cash, the Company may choose to borrow against its revolving credit
	facility or utilize its commercial paper program.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company&#146;s outstanding debt at December&nbsp;31, 2016 was $3,214&nbsp;million and consisted of
	$499&nbsp;million in 1.35% Senior Notes, $1,391&nbsp;million in 2.60% Senior Notes, $1,087&nbsp;million in 3.95% Senior Notes, no commercial paper borrowings, and other debt of $237&nbsp;million. The Company was in compliance with all covenants at
	December&nbsp;31, 2016.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	At December&nbsp;31, 2016, there were no commercial paper borrowings supported by the $4.5&nbsp;billion credit facility and no
	outstanding letters of credit issued under the credit facility, resulting in $4,500&nbsp;million of funds available under this revolving credit facility.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The Company had $1,196&nbsp;million of outstanding letters of credit at December&nbsp;31, 2016 that are under various bilateral letter of credit facilities.
	Letters of credit are issued as bid bonds, advanced payment bonds and performance bonds. The following table summarizes our net cash provided by continuing operating activities, net cash used in continuing investing activities and net cash used in
	continuing financing activities for the periods presented (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>

<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Operating Activities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 vs 2015.
</I>
	Net cash provided by continuing operating activities was $960&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to net cash provided by continuing operating
	activities of $1,332&nbsp;million in 2015. Before changes in operating assets and liabilities, net of acquisitions, cash was used by continuing operations primarily through loss from continuing operations of $2,416&nbsp;million plus
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	charges of $2,305&nbsp;million, $6&nbsp;million in a dividend received from Voest-Alpine Tubulars, an unconsolidated affiliate, and $21&nbsp;million in equity loss in unconsolidated affiliates.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net changes in operating assets and liabilities, net of acquisitions, provided $1,044&nbsp;million of cash in 2016 compared to $466&nbsp;million used in the
	same period in 2015. The decrease in cash used in 2016 compared to the same period in 2015 was primarily due to declines in accounts receivable, inventory and costs in excess of billings, partially offset by declines in accounts payable, accrued
	liabilities and billings in excess of costs.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 vs 2014.
</I>
	Net cash provided by continuing operating activities was $1,332&nbsp;million in 2015
	compared to net cash provided by continuing operating activities of $2,525&nbsp;million in 2014. Before changes in operating assets and liabilities, net of acquisitions, cash was provided by continuing operations primarily through loss from
	continuing operations of $767&nbsp;million plus
<FONT STYLE="WHITE-SPACE:NOWRAP">
	non-cash
</FONT>
	charges of $2,544&nbsp;million, plus $34&nbsp;million in a dividend received from Voest-Alpine Tubulars, an unconsolidated affiliate, less
	$13&nbsp;million in equity income.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	Net changes in operating assets and liabilities, net of acquisitions, used $466&nbsp;million of cash in 2015 compared
	to $794&nbsp;million used in the same period in 2014. The decrease in cash used in 2015 compared to the same period in 2014 was the result of a decline in accounts receivable and inventory; partially offset by a decline in accounts payable and
	decreased orders in the Rig Systems segment which is reflected in customer financing, where revenue recognized outpaced prepayments and milestone invoicing on major projects.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT ; FONT-SIZE:8PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN" ALIGN="CENTER">
	42
</P>
<A NAME="eolPage44"></A>
<P STYLE='PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
<HR SIZE="3" STYLE="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<H5 ALIGN="LEFT">
<A HREF="#D313669D10K_HTM_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</H5>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:0PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Investing Activities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 vs 2015.
</I>
	Net cash used in continuing investing activities was $488&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to net cash used in continuing investing
	activities of $514&nbsp;million in 2015. Net cash used in continuing investing activities was primarily the result of decreased capital expenditures in 2016 compared to 2015, offset by an increase in cash used for acquisitions. The Company used
	$284&nbsp;million during 2016 for capital expenditures compared to $453&nbsp;million in 2015 and $230&nbsp;million for acquisitions during 2016, compared to $86&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 vs 2014.
</I>
	Net cash used in continuing investing activities was $514&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to net cash used in continuing investing
	activities of $1,092&nbsp;million in 2014. Net cash used in continuing investing activities was primarily the result of capital expenditures and acquisition activity both of which decreased in 2015 compared to 2014. The Company used
	$453&nbsp;million during 2015 for capital expenditures compared to $699&nbsp;million in 2014 and $86&nbsp;million for acquisitions during 2015, compared to $291&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Financing Activities
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2016 vs 2015.
</I>
	Net
	cash used in continuing financing activities was $1,141&nbsp;million in 2016 compared to $2,163&nbsp;million in 2015. This decrease was primarily the result of $900&nbsp;million used to make payments on net commercial paper borrowings in 2016
	compared to $762&nbsp;million of net commercial paper borrowings in 2015 used to purchase $2,221&nbsp;million (44.0&nbsp;million shares) of the Company&#146;s outstanding common shares. In addition, the Company decreased its dividend to
	$230&nbsp;million during 2016 compared to $710&nbsp;million in 2015.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<I>
	2015 vs 2014.
</I>
	Net cash used in continuing financing activities was
	$2,163&nbsp;million in 2015 compared to $1,343&nbsp;million in 2014. This increase was primarily the result of $2,221&nbsp;million used to repurchase and retire 44.0&nbsp;million of the Company&#146;s common shares outstanding during 2015. In order
	to fund a large portion of the share repurchases, the Company entered into net commercial paper borrowings of $893&nbsp;million during 2015. The Company repaid $151&nbsp;million of Senior Notes in the third quarter of 2015. In addition, the Company
	increased its dividend to $710&nbsp;million during 2015 compared to $703&nbsp;million in 2014.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:18PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
<B>
<I>
	Other
</I>
</B>
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:6PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	The effect of the change in exchange rates on cash was a decrease of $3&nbsp;million, $111&nbsp;million and $67&nbsp;million for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, respectively.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We believe that cash on hand, cash generated from operations and amounts available under our credit
	facilities and from other sources of debt will be sufficient to fund operations, working capital needs, capital expenditure requirements, dividends and financing obligations.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	We intend to pursue additional acquisition candidates, but the timing, size or success of any acquisition effort and the related potential capital commitments
	cannot be predicted. We continue to expect to fund future cash acquisitions primarily with cash flow from operations and borrowings, including the unborrowed portion of the revolving credit facility or new debt issuances, but may also issue
	additional equity either directly or in connection with acquisitions. There can be no assurance that additional financing for acquisitions will be available at terms acceptable to us.
</P>
<P STYLE="MARGIN-TOP:12PT; MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT; FONT-SIZE:10PT; FONT-FAMILY:TIMES NEW ROMAN">
	A summary of the Company&#146;s outstanding contractual obligations at December&nbsp;31, 2016 is as follows (in millions):
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-SIZE:12PT;MARGIN-TOP:0PT;MARGIN-BOTTOM:0PT">
	&nbsp;
</P>
